name: favoured
content:
favoured

adjective
 
/ˈfeɪvəd/
 
/ˈfeɪvərd/
(US English favored)
jump to other results
  1. treated in a special way or receiving special help or advantages in a way that may seem unfair
    • a member of the President’s favoured circle of advisers
  2. preferred by most people
    • the favoured candidate
    Topics Preferences and decisionsc2
  3. (formal) particularly pleasant and worth having
    • Their house is in a very favoured position near the park.
See favoured in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: favoured

name: favour
content:
favour

verb
 OPAL W
 
/ˈfeɪvə(r)/
 
/ˈfeɪvər/
(US English favor)
Verb Forms
present simple I / you / we / they favour
 
/ˈfeɪvə(r)/
 
/ˈfeɪvər/
he / she / it favours
 
/ˈfeɪvəz/
 
/ˈfeɪvərz/
past simple favoured
 
/ˈfeɪvəd/
 
/ˈfeɪvərd/
past participle favoured
 
/ˈfeɪvəd/
 
/ˈfeɪvərd/
-ing form favouring
 
/ˈfeɪvərɪŋ/
 
/ˈfeɪvərɪŋ/
Idioms
jump to other results

    prefer

  1.  
     to prefer one system, plan, way of doing something, etc. to another
    • favour something Many countries favour a presidential system of government.
    • It’s a resort favoured by families with young children.
    • Another solution, which I strongly favour, is lower taxes for everyone.
    • With make-up I favour a minimalist approach.
    • favour something over something She favours hugs over handshakes.
    • favour doing something Most patients favour seeing the same GP for all their health needs.
    Extra Examples
    • We strongly favour reform of the system.
    • Black voters overwhelmingly favour the Democratic Party.
    • Haitians especially favour seafoods.
    • I personally favour this last option.
    • Pot plants are increasingly favoured as gifts by guests.
    • She continues to favour large-scale developments.
    • The Democrat candidate is favoured for re-election.
    • The polls slightly favour the Republicans.
    • The prime minister is thought to favour an early referendum on the issue.
    Topics Preferences and decisionsb2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadverb
    • greatly
    • heavily
    • overwhelmingly
    • …
    verb + favour/​favor
    • appear to
    • be known to
    • be likely to
    • …
    preposition
    • at the expense of
    • for
    • over
    • …
    See full entry
    2.

    treat better

  2.  
     to treat one person, group or organization better than you treat others, especially in an unfair way
    • favour somebody/something The treaty seems to favour the US.
    • My parents always favoured my older brother.
    • He favoured some individuals at the expense of others.
    • favour somebody/something over somebody/something News coverage should not favour one party over another.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadverb
    • greatly
    • heavily
    • overwhelmingly
    • …
    verb + favour/​favor
    • appear to
    • be known to
    • be likely to
    • …
    preposition
    • at the expense of
    • for
    • over
    • …
    See full entry
    3.

    help

  3. favour something to provide suitable conditions for a particular person, group, etc.
    • The warm climate favours many types of tropical plants.
    4.

    look like parent

  4. favour somebody (old-fashioned or North American English, informal) to look like one of your parents or older relations
    • She definitely favours her father.
    5. Word OriginMiddle English (in the noun sense ‘liking, preference’): via Old French from Latin favor, from favere ‘show kindness to’ (related to fovere ‘cherish’).
Idioms
be favoured to do something
  1. to be expected to achieve something, especially in a competition
    • He is favoured to win a third Olympic gold medal.
See favour in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: favour
matches: the cards/odds are stacked in your favour
load the dice (against/in favour of somebody)
relatives: the cards/odds are stacked in your favour
load the dice (against/in favour of somebody)
the cards/odds are stacked in your favour
load the dice (against/in favour of somebody)

name: most favoured nation
content:
most favoured nation

noun
 
/ˌməʊst feɪvəd ˈneɪʃn/
 
/ˌməʊst feɪvərd ˈneɪʃn/
(US English most favored nation)
jump to other results
  1. a country to which another country allows the most advantages in trade, because they have a good relationship
Check pronunciation: most favoured nation

name: most favoured nation
content:
most favoured nation

noun
 
/ˌməʊst feɪvəd ˈneɪʃn/
 
/ˌməʊst feɪvərd ˈneɪʃn/
(US English most favored nation)
jump to other results
  1. a country to which another country allows the most advantages in trade, because they have a good relationship
